In this session we will continue to discuss from the twentieth verse of the twelfth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
The previous session we discussed one part of the purport of this twentieth verse.
In this session we will discuss the second part of the purport of this twentieth verse.
Just to refresh your memory the twentieth verse is as follows.
So the meaning of this twentieth verse is
This child will be a munificent donor of charity and protector of the surrendered
like the famous king Shastra.
And he will expand the name and fame of his family like Bharata, the son of Maharaj Dushyanta.
In a previous session we discussed about Maharaj Shibi.
Now we will discuss about Bharata, the son of Maharaj Dushyanta.
So in the purport Srila Prabhupada briefly mentions the history of this Bharata, the son of Maharaj Dushyanta.
First of all Srila Prabhupada says
There are many Bharatas in history of which three are very famous.
Three Bharatas are famous.
Who are the three Bharatas who are very famous?
The first one is the Bharata who is the brother of the king.
The brother of Lord Ramachandra, who is actually the son of Dasharatha Maharaj, that Bharata.
You can say Dasharathi Bharata.
The second Bharata who is famous in history, Vedic history is Bharata, the son of king
Rishabha.
The Lord appeared as Rishabhadeva, king Rishabhadeva, emperor of the world.
And he had one hundred sons.
Of these one hundred sons, the eldest one was Bharata Maharaj.
That Bharata Maharaj, he renounced his kingdom at a very young age, practiced very nice austerities
and became advanced spiritually.
But towards the end of his life, when he was performing tapasya, after retiring from
his kingdom, he got attached to a deer and he had to take a deer's body in his next life.
Even though he was spiritually very advanced and he was given remembrance of his spiritual
activities by Krishna within his heart, even in the body of a deer.
And he was very, very cautious not to get misled by any material.
Even in the body of a deer.
And then he was again given a chance to take birth in a brahmana family.
And in that life, third life, he perfected himself and went back to God.
So that Bharata is also famous, the second Bharata.
And the third Bharata who is famous is mentioned in this verse.
Bharata, the son of Maharaj Dushyanta.
He is also very famous.
So, all these Bharatas are historically known to the universe.
See the scriptures describe universal history.
And nowadays, the discussion about history is only about some incidents that happened
on this planet in the past.
But various literature are describing to us the history of the universe.
There are millions of them.

is eternal.
So all these are described in the Vedic literature, the Vedic scriptures.
So the Vedic scriptures give us knowledge which is comprehensive and vast as compared
to the body of knowledge that we have in our modern day.
The Vedic scriptures give us knowledge which is very, very, very, very limited and tiny
and incomplete, imperfect knowledge.

So this Bharata was famous for
performing many many sacrifices.
A king should perform sacrifices for the sake of the welfare of the whole kingdom.
Because in the Bhagavad Gita it is explained that
annad bhavanti bhutani parjanyad anna sambhavah yajnyad bhavati parjanyo yajna karma samutbhavah
There is a cycle that is operating in this earth planet.
What is that? That all living beings subsist on food grains directly or indirectly.
The vegetarians directly subsist on food grains.
But the non-vegetarians they subsist on animals who subsist on food grains.
So therefore directly or indirectly all living beings are dependent on food grains.
And the food grains are due to rains, proper rainfall.
We know that when there is excessive rain or there is scarcity of rain
then there is no proper production of grains.
So production of grains, sufficient quantity of grains for all creatures, humans and the animals and the other birds etc.
depends on proper rainfall.
Because we cannot manufacture food grains in factories and industries and all kinds of scientific research.
We cannot manufacture food grains.
It has to be grown on the land, fertile land.
And even if the land is fertile, unless there is proper rainfall, you cannot get sufficient grains production.
So now the rains are dependent on
yajñād bhavati parjanyo
Parjanyo means rainfall.
Rainfall is dependent on proper performance of yajña.
So yajña performance by the human beings ensures adequate rainfall, not too much, not too little.
And if there is proper rainfall, there is plenty of grain production.
And that grain production will nourish
all creatures on this earth planet, human beings and the lower creatures also, everyone.
And this is the arrangement of the Supreme Lord.
Yajña karma samudbhavaha
Yajña means to perform prescribed duties, not self-assumed duties.
Nowadays people think, oh my duty is something, according to what I think is my duty.
No.
Duty is something that is prescribed in this jastra for the overall welfare of the entire population of this world.
Otherwise, by artificial means, we cannot get our necessities.
Not possible.
There will only be a failure of the administrators to provide for the necessities of the people.
Of the country by artificial methods is not going to work.
So Bhagavad Gita says the natural method is they should perform yajña.
And the foremost person to perform yajña is the king, the ruler, the leader of all the people in the world.
He should perform yajña.
And when he performs yajña, there is prosperity for all the people of the country.
And this Dushyanta was famous for having performed many sacrifices.
Similarly, Pariksit also will perform sacrifices for the welfare of the entire kingdom.
And there will be prosperity because of this child growing up to rule the whole world.
That is what is being foretold by the brahmanas to King Yudhishthira.
I will stop here. Thank you very much. Hare Krishna.
